physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Aldington" in pencil at the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am sorry to hear that Richard has already gone. He wrote me a letter, which I just received, saying that when I got it he would be in France. You must be fearfully lonely, and I wish I were with you to give what little comfort I could.

Should you decide to come to America, please let me know at once, for I shall want to see you as soon as possible. I am going on to New York on Wednesday, to be there three weeks, so if you come soon, I may be able to meet you.

You know I am lecturing about you at the Brooklyn Institute of Fine Arts and Sciences. You never answered my letter requesting a slight biography, so I was obliged to write to your mother, who gave me merely the barest facts, as, she said, you were always so reticent about yourself. I do wish you would give me some anecdotes, though, which I can work in when the book is published. All the other poets I have spoken to have done so, and I think it makes things interesting. There are four lectures, which are to be divided as follows: 1. Edwin Arlington Robinson 2. Robert Frost 3. Edgar Lee Masters and Carl Sandburg 4. John Gould Fletcher and H.D., and I hope to be able to do you justice.

I have read your book through with the feeling of greatest envy and admiration. No one of us is so perfect in technique as you; and the beauty of your work never ceases to satisfy me. I only hope that these lectures and the book may be a means of making more people understand you than do now. The public is a stupid beast.

I have sent some of Richard’s poems to "The Seven Arts", and I hope they will accept some. Brown still owes Richard five dollars on my agreement. He told me he would pay me last week, but, of course, it has not come. I probably shall get it, however, before long.
body.closer: Keep me informed as to Richard’s movements, and your own, please, and believe me, Always affectionately,
